Build ID: I20070921-0919

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Create a jar with a class test.TestClass
2. copy the jar into the lib/ext folder of the JRE (e.g. at openSuse 10.3 this is /usr/lib/jvm/java-1.6.0.u1-sun-1.6.0.u1/jre/lib/ext)
3. Restart Eclipse, so it finds the jar at the restart
4. Create a new Eclipse plugin, e.g using the "Hello,World" template
5. Add the code "new TestClass()" (with the right import) somewhere in the plugin. 
6. Run Eclipse with that plugin. When trying to call the TestClass constructor, a NoClassDefFoundError is thrown with a stacktrace like that:

java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: test/TestClass
at testplugin.actions.SampleAction.run(SampleAction.java:39)
at org.eclipse.ui.internal.PluginAction.runWithEvent(PluginAction.java:256)
at org.eclipse.ui.internal.WWinPluginAction.runWithEvent(WWinPluginAction.java:229)
...


More information:
Obviously the classloader of the plugin is able to load the classes from the lib/rt.jar of the JRE, but not the classes from any jar in the lib/ext folder, even though they are also part of the JRE.

It is by design that Eclipse does not give bundles free access to the classes available from the extension classloader.  The extension classloader from the VM is not manageable.  Instead of placing content in the installed VM the recommended way is to install the content within a bundle/plugin.

If you really want to use things from the ext classloader then you must set the following config.ini property

osgi.parentClassloader=ext
